message_1:
Find the radius of convergence and interval of convergence for the power series:

$$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-3)^n}{n+1}z^{n+1}$$
message_2:
To find the radius of convergence, we can use the Ratio Test. The Ratio Test states that if the limit as n approaches infinity of the absolute value of the ratio of consecutive terms of a series is less than 1, then the series converges. In this case, we have:

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right| = \lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{\frac{(-3)^{n+1}}{n+2}z^{n+2}}{\frac{(-3)^n}{n+1}z^{n+1}}\right|$$

Simplify the expression:

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{(-3)^{n+1}(n+1)z^{n+1}}{(-3)^n(n+2)z^{n+2}}\right|$$

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{(-3)(n+1)}{(n+2)}\right|$$

Now, we want this limit to be less than 1 for convergence:

$$\left|\frac{(-3)(n+1)}{(n+2)}\right| < 1$$

As n approaches infinity, the limit becomes:

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{-3}{1}\right| = 3$$

Since the limit is greater than 1, the series diverges for all z. Therefore, the radius of convergence is 0.

The interval of convergence is the set of all z values for which the series converges. Since the radius of convergence is 0, the interval of convergence is the empty set, meaning there are no values of z for which the series converges.
